Highlights
 Comparing adsorption of Lead (II) ions for Chitosan nanoparticles
and chitin nanofibers
 Novel synthesized method for chitin nanofibers
 Thermodynamic and kinetics studies for chitin nanofibers and
chitosan nanoparticles
 High adsorbed lead for both adsorbents
 Better adsorption for chitosan nanoparticles in comparison of
chitin nanofibers
Abstract
Low-cost and biocompatible chitin nanofiber and chitosan nanoparticle as natural polymers
synthesized successfully by means of a mechanical and a chemical procedure respectively. The surface properties and size of chitin nanofibers (CNFs) and chitosan nanoparticles (CNPs) were characterized using a scanning electron microscope (SEM). CNF and CNP were utilized for separation of lead(II) metal ions from aqueous solution, and the influence of effective factors were investigated. It was found that both adsorbents can adsorb lead ions from the solution effectively, but sorption efficiency for CNP at all the stages was greater than CNF. Furthermore, the results of corresponding equilibrium data with adsorption isotherms revealed that CNF and CNP are more compatible with Freundlich and Langmuir adsorption isotherms respectively. It shows that, for CNF, adsorption process occurs as a heterogeneous and multi-layer process, while for CNP, adsorption process is predicted to befall as a homogenous and single-layer process. At the end kinetics and thermodynamic studies were performed for both Nanoadsorbents.
Keywords: Lead(II) removal, Chitin nanofibers, Chitosan nanoparticles, kinetics study,
thermodynamic study, biocompatible polymer

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The problem of water pollution in recent decades by heavy metals makes it necessary to treat contaminated water before discharging it to the water resources (Heidari, Younesi, Mehraban & Heikkinen, 2013; Salam, Reiad & ElShafei, 2011). Heavy metals arrive into water resources in different ways by various industries. Some heavy metals are poisonous even at low concentrations and in the case of accumulation in living organisms, can impair in their performance (JIANG, SUN, SUN & LI, 2006; Karnib, Kabbani, Holail & Olama, 2014; Mendoza-Castillo et al., 2015). Lead is a naturally occurring element found in small amounts in the earth's crust. Lead generates a variety of diseases and disorders in the human body. According to the World Health Organization standards, the maximum allowable limit of lead in drinking water is 0.01 mg/l(Organization, 2014) while the average Pb(II) ions concentration in the storage battery industry wastewater found 3.0 mg/l(Bahadir, Bakan, Altas & Buyukgungor, 2007). Therefore, appropriate treatment of lead contaminated wastewater is of great concern prior to discharging it into the water resources (Fu & Wang, 2011; Kamaraj, Ganesan & Vasudevan, 2015; Şölener, Tunali, Özcan, Özcan & Gedikbey, 2008).
Heavy metals can be separated and recovered by means of different methods such as
chemical precipitation, ion exchange, and electrochemical removal. These methods have significant disadvantages like partial removal, high-energy necessities, and the invention of poisonous sludge, which should be wiped out to reduce environmental impacts (Barakat, 2011; Faridbod, Jamali, Ganjali, Hosseini & Norouzi, 2015; Tofighy & Mohammadi, 2011). Another technique for separation of heavy metals from wastewater is adsorption. Adsorption is suggested as a rapid and efficient method for removing heavy metals from aqueous systems especially in the cases that the concentration of heavy metals is low. The adsorption process involves a solid adsorbent, which binds the molecules through chemical bonding, ion exchange and physical attractive forces (Demirbas, 2008). One of the issues raised in the absorption method, is the selection of convenient adsorbent. Activated carbon and its derivatives have been used the most as the adsorbent. In spite of its broad use in removing heavy metals from industry discharges, activated carbon remains an expensive adsorbent (Hegazi, 2013; Onundi, Mamun, Al Khatib, Al Saadi & Suleyman, 2011; Sheet, Kabbani & Holail, 2014).
As an alternative to expensive activated carbon, inexpensive and inoffensive adsorbents
that are naturally found in the nature, have attracted much attentions (Bailey, Olin, Bricka & Adrian, 1999). Chitin and chitosan are the naturally plentiful and renewable polymers that have outstanding features such as biodegradability, biocompatibility, nontoxicity and adsorption capability (Dutta, Dutta & Tripathi, 2004). Chitin is the second most plentiful polysaccharide after cellulose in the nature that can be easily obtained from seafood industry waste products. Chitin is a biocompatible, nontoxic, inexpensive and antimicrobial material which is broadly used as a substance to adsorb heavy metals, due to its efficient chelation sufficiency to heavy metal ions in aqueous solutions (Mushi, Butchosa, Salajkova, Zhou & Berglund, 2014). Chitin Nanofibers are generally described as fibers with the diameter size less than 100 nanometers (Qi & Xu, 2004; Xia et al., 2003). Chitosan is N-deacetylated derivative of chitin, although Ndeacetylation is practically never complete. Chitosan has the same favorable characteristics of chitin, moreover due to free amino groups possesses more adsorption capability (Kumar, 2000; Tirgar, Golbabaei, Hamedi, Nourijelyani, Shahtaheri & Moosavi, 2006). In recent years, for increasing the efficiency of pollutant elimination of water resources, the attentions have been focused on nano-adsorbents production. Nano-adsorbents due to some profits such as high permeability and high specific surface area per unit mass can sufficiently increase the adsorption capacity (Liu, Zhu, Li, Tian, Chen & Chen, 2013).
In previous investigations, there are reports, focused on heavy metal removal from aqueous
solution using chitin and chitosan and their derivatives (Bailey, Olin, Bricka & Adrian, 1999; Bhatnagar & Sillanpää, 2009; Kumar, 2000). The objective of this study is to employ inexpensive and environmentally friendly chitin and chitosan nano-adsorbents for elimination of lead (II) metal ions, and study different effective parameters on removal efficiency. In this study for the first time, nanofibers and nanoparticles of chitin and chitosan were used to remove lead metal ions from aqueous solution. This research exhibits particular features of nano-adsorbents for their small size and great surface area, which lead to higher capacities for metal ion separation. Furthermore, removal proficiency of chitin and chitosan nano-adsorbents are compared at all the stages. At the end, equilibrium data are fitted to Langmuir and Freundlich
adsorption isotherms to determine the best describing adsorption process. In addition, Kinetics and Thermodynamic studies performed for both Nano-adsorbent

sections.heading: 2.1. Reagents and Solutions
sections.text: Raw chitin powder, chitosan and sodium tripolyphosphate were purchased from SigmaAldrich chemical co. and used throughout this investigation. Lead (II) nitrate salt was provided from Sigma-Aldrich chemical co. Acetic acid, HCl, NaOH and deionized distilled water were purchased from Merck chemical co. (Darmstadt, Germany). The lead (II) ion solutions for adsorption experiments with different concentrations varied from 2 to 140 ppm was prepared by dissolving Pb(NO3)2 at different amounts in deionized distilled water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Instruments
sections.text: A scanning electron microscope (SEM, XL30, Philips and Netherlands) was used in order to characterize the morphology and the size of chitin and chitosan nano-adsorbents. A Varian model AA-400 atomic absorption spectrometer (Varian, Musgrave, Australia), equipped with a deuterium lamp background and a hollow cathode lamp, was used for determination of lead(II) metal ions concentration. All measurements were carried out in a peak height mode. Operating parameters were set as recommended by the manufacturer. IR spectra were recorded using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet IR100 (Madison, WI) Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer. A digital pH-meter (Metrohm, model 692, Herisau, Switzerland), equipped with a glass-combination electrode was used for the pH adjustment.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of chitin Nanofibers
sections.text: Preparation of nanofiber is an important subject because of their special optical, mechanical, dimensional and other characteristics. Firstly 10 g raw powder of chitin microfibers was added to deionized water to prepare a suspension with the concentration of 1% wt/wt, and then the suspension was stirred for 12 h at 25° C. secondly, the suspension was poured into a machine mill (MKCA6-3; Masuko Sangyo Co., Ltd., Japan). The suspension was passed through the machine with a flow rate of 10 l/h for 15 cycles. The machine has two grinding stones, one is fixed and the other is rotating. As the microfibers passing between the rocks, because of shear and compressive forces fibrillation process occurs at the nano scale.

sections.heading: 2.4. Preparation of chitosan Nanoparticles
sections.text: The method presented is as reported by Lifeng Qi et al.(Qi, Xu, Jiang, Hu & Zou, 2004) Chitosan was dissolved at the concentration of 0.5% (w/v) in acetic acid 1% (v/v) and then raised to pH=4.6–4.8 with 10 N sodium hydroxide. Upon addition of 1ml of an aqueous sodium tripolyphosphate solution with the concentration of 0.25% (w/v) to 3 ml of chitosan solution under magnetic stirring chitosan nanoparticles shaped spontaneously. Nanoparticles were purified by centrifugation at 9000 rpm for 30 min. Supernatants were discarded, and the chitosan nanoparticles were extensively rinsed with deionized distilled water to remove any sodium hydroxide and thereafter freeze-dried before further use or analysis.

sections.heading: 2.5. Adsorption Procedure
sections.text:
The adsorption of lead (II) metal ions on CNF and CNP was passed using a batch system.
Adsorption experiments were performed in a 250 ml glass-stoppered flask containing 100 ml of lead (II) solution under magnetic stirring. For this purpose, specific amount of Nano-adsorbents were suspended in deionized distilled water and well sonicated. Then different solutions containing lead (II) metal ions with fixed concentrations were added, and adsorption experiments were accomplished at various contact times. After equilibrium, the suspension was centrifuged for 3 min at 16,000 rpm to eliminate Nano-adsorbents that have adsorbed metal ions. Lead (II) metal ion concentration in the remaining supernatant was measured using Flame Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer (FAAS). Adsorbent dose was selected 1 g/l and the pH of working media was adjusted in 5 because the maximum amount of lead uptake was obtained in pH value equal to 5. Lead ions adsorption dependents upon protonation of amine and carboxyl functional groups of the adsorbents. By lowering the pH value, functional groups are protonated and consequently the amount of accessibility of lead ions to the active sites decreases. Furthermore, functional groups protonation causes electrostatic repulsion between positively charged lead ions and positively charged protonated functional groups which results more decrease in lead ions adsorption. As the pH value rises, the density of the negative charge on the functional groups increases and lead uptake amount rises due to electrostatic attraction. In pH values beyond 5, in which the solution alkalinity approaches to basic solution, lead ions precipitate out and it causes error in adsorption experiments. Adsorption experiments applying various initial concentration have been conducted in a volume of 100 ml with initial concentration of lead (II) varying from 40 to 140 ppm at the temperature of 298.15 K for 60 min. This contact time was selected because after 60 min any significant increase in adsorption of lead ions was not observed. In addition according to the literature, required process time for reaching the equilibrium was approximately 60 min(Qi & Xu, 2004). Furthermore, for lower concentrations (2-10 ppm) all experiments were performed with above conditions. For thermodynamic study, the procedure was performed at 298.15, 313.15 and 328.15 K. All adsorption experiments were repeated five times under identical conditions. The amount of lead ions adsorbed (lead uptake) is obtained by the following equation (1):
𝑞𝑒 = (𝐶0 − 𝐶𝑒) ∗ 𝑉
𝑊 (1)
Where 𝑞𝑒 is the adsorbed lead (mg/g),𝐶0 and 𝐶𝑒 are initial and equilibrium concentrations of lead (II) ions (mg/l) respectively, 𝑉 is the solution volume (l), and 𝑊is the mass of adsorbent (g). Removal efficiency is achieved by equation (2):
𝑅𝐸% = (𝐶0 − 𝐶𝑒)
𝐶0 ∗ 100 (2)
where 𝑅𝐸% refers to removal efficiency.
During the adsorption experiments, the effect of initial concentration, adsorbent dose,
contact time and pH value on the amount of adsorbed lead were studied, and equilibrium data were fitted into Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm models to investigate the adsorption performance of the adsorbents.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of Nano-adsorbents
sections.text: The preparation of the Nano-adsorbent was simple and properly efficient. CNFs were produced by means of a mechanical fibrillation procedure, using a machine mill, and the preparation of CNPs were founded on an ionic gelation interaction between positively-charged chitosan and negatively-charged tripolyphosphate at room temperature. A scanning electron microscope (SEM) was utilized for characterizing the size and morphology of Nano-adsorbents. Fig. 1 (a and b) shows SEM images of CNFs and CNPs respectively. As presented in the figures, shape and size of Nano-adsorbents can be characterized satisfactorily. CNFs exhibit a permeable network shape, in which most of the fibers have a diameter size about 60 nm and CNPs exhibit a particle shape, in which most of the particles have a diameter size about 70 nm.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of initial concentration
sections.text:
The Effect of initial metal concentration on lead elimination was investigated by batch adsorption experiments. The amount of adsorbed lead, greatly depends on the initial concentration of metal ions.
As presented in Figure 2, by increasing the initial concentration from 2 to 140 ppm and
keeping all the other parameters constant, the ratio of lead(II) ions to the adsorbent amount and consequently, the ratio of lead(II) ions to active sites increases. Hence, more lead(II) ions are available for active sites to react with and thus, lead uptake rises as a result. At very high initial concentrations, adsorbed lead remains almost constant, due to active site saturation by metal ions (Sivakami, Gomathi, Venkatesan, Jeong, Kim & Sudha, 2013). As Figure 2 represents, beyond the concentrations of 100 ppm of lead ions, meaningful changes in lead ions adsorption were not observed. So 100 ppm was chosed as the best point for further experiments.
The results of the experiments show that, CNF and CNP can eliminate lead ions quickly
and, exhibit a high amount of lead uptake. Therefore, these adsorbents can be used as a satisfactory alternative to synthetic adsorbents such as activated carbon, especially when the concentration of heavy metals is low. In addition, these adsorbents due to biocompatibility and biodegradability comprise less environmental impacts.
For lower concentrations (2-10 ppm) experiments were performed and result showed that
there were not almost any lead ions in remaining solution and removal efficiency of lead ions were obtained 96% to 100% (Table 1).

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of pH
sections.text:
The pH of the solution has a major impact on the lead uptake amount since it controls the surface charge of the adsorbent and the degree of ionization of the adsorbate (Cho, Oh & Kim, 2005). The effect of pH value on the adsorbed lead amount by CNFs and CNPs were investigated, and the results are shown in Figure 3.
As presented in Figure 3, adsorbed lead for both Nano-adsorbents increase
significantly with the increase of pH value, so that maximum lead uptake can be seen at the pH equal to 5 (red bar). If the initial pH was too high, lead metal ions precipitated out, and this would avert the aim of engaging the adsorption method, since the adsorption method is kinetically faster than the precipitation.(Amarasinghe & Williams, 2007) At the lower pH values (pH<5), due to heightening the concentration of protons, a competition between protons and lead ions for occupying active sites occurs, and lead uptake decreases as a result. In addition, as the pH value reduces, the amount of protonation of functional groups rises, which lead to less lead uptake due to electrostatic repulsion between positively charged functional groups and positively charged lead ions (Sankararamakrishnan, Sharma & Sanghi, 2007; Sreejalekshmi, Krishnan & Anirudhan, 2009). As showed in Figure 3, maximum adsorption occurred in pH equal to 5. In pH values beyond 5 in which the solution alkalinity approaches to basic solution, lead ions precipitate out and it causes error in adsorption experiments. pH equal to 5 is the optimum pH for some reasons: first, it lowers probability of lead precipitation as Pb(OH)2, second, according to primary experiments which are presented in Fig. 3 we have the maximum lead uptake and third, this pH is near to solution primary pH, so sample experimental preparation is easier.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of the Nano-adsorbent dose
sections.text:
The results of the investigation with varying adsorbent dosage are illustrated in Figure 4. With an increase in the adsorbent dosage from 1 to 3 g/l, the amount of heavy metal adsorption increased for both adsorbents. As the number of active sites in the solution increases, more metal ions have availability to active sites to react with, and heavy metal adsorption increases as a result. On the other hand, the adsorbed lead amount for CNFs decreased from 65 mg/g to 50.3 mg/g and, for CNPs decreased from 93.5 mg/g to 72.3 mg/g. This decrease in adsorbed lead amount is due to enhancing the ratio of active sites to lead(II) ions which is completely consistent with equation (1).
(Sivakami, Gomathi, Venkatesan, Jeong, Kim & Sudha, 2013; Şölener, Tunali, Özcan,
Özcan & Gedikbey, 2008)

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
According to hard and soft acid-base theory, lead has high tendency to oxygen and nitrogen groups, so as shown in figure 5, complexation is likely the adsorption mechanism. Complexation likely occur between nitrogen and oxygen atoms with lead ions, because lead has empty orbitals that can be occupied by electrons of oxygen and nitrogen.(McIlwee, Schauer, Praig, Boukherroub & Szunerits, 2008)
Figure 5 signifies the mechanism of lead(II) ion complexation with chitosan.
Pb2+ + RNH2 Pb(RNH2)2+ (3)
The amine groups of chitosan are protonated as follows:

sections.heading: H+ + RNH2 RNH3+ (4)
sections.text:
According to precedent equations, chitosan and metal ions will be positively charged at
low pHs, so repulsive forces occur between chitosan and metal ions instead of attraction. However, by increasing the alkalinity of the solution, a reverse phenomenon will take place, leading to higher absorption of the metal cations. The same adsorption mechanism is happening for chitin, except that chitin has –NCOCH3 instead of –NH agents which causes weaker complexation between chitin and lead ions (Cadogan, Lee, Popuri & Lin, 2015; Guibal, 2004). The higher ΔH° value for CNP (thermodynamic study) is a sign of higher accessibility to active sites in comparison with CNF. Reaction between CNP-Pb is more spontaneous than CNF-Pb and the process occurs thermodynamically preferable for CNP-Pb due to better ΔG°, ΔH° and ΔS° (Table 4). Isotherm study shows another reason for better adsorption process for CNP. As can be seen in Table 3, maximum adsorption capacity is more for CNPs than CNFs.
The mechanism of lead (II) ions removal by chitin nanofibers is governed by lewis acid-
base theory. The lone pair electrons on O and N of the respective hydroxyl and acetamide groups present in chitin nanofibers react with lead ions vacant orbitals and lead ions are adsorbed on chitin nanofibers surface.
The FTIR spectra of CNPs, and CNP-Lead(II) complexes were acquired to provide a direct
readout of complex formation.
The peak around 3385 cm−1 in figure 6a was assigned to the -NH2 and -OH groups of
CNPs, and the absorption bands of CNP-Lead(II) complexes were much lower than that of CNPs. Moreover, the absorption bands at 1654 cm−1 (νNH), 1,389 cm−1 (νCN) and 1,253 cm−1 (νCN) shifted to lower frequencies or decreased (Figure 6c), further demonstrating that the lead ions interacted with the -NH2 groups of CNPs. Similarly, the absorption bands at 1,081 cm−1 (νCOH) and 1,156 cm−1 (νC-O-C) decreased or disappeared, indicating that the metal ions also reacted with -OH groups in spite of the weak interactions. Additionally, the red shift or disappearance of the band at 2,880 cm−1 (νC-H) and the decrease of the band at 892 cm−1 (corresponding to the ring
stretching vibration of CNP skeleton) suggested that the coordination of metal ions weaken the skeleton vibration of CNP, thus leading to the change in amorphous structure of CNP.(Del Aguila, Gomes, Trist & Silva, 2012; Fernandes, Resende, Tavares, Soares, Castro & Granjeiro, 2011) In brief, the interaction of CNP (-NH2 and -OH) and the lead ions caused a decrease in electron density of -NH2 and -OH and reduced the bond force constant of CNP chemical bonds, subsequently related band absorptions all shifted to lower frequencies. As can be seen in figure 6b the FTIR spectra of CNFs exhibited major peaks at 3446 cm-1 for –OH stretching vibration, 3260 cm-1 for –NH stretching vibration, 1660 cm-1 (amide I), 1623 and 1557 cm-1 (amide II).(Fernandes, Resende, Tavares, Soares, Castro & Granjeiro, 2011) absorption bands of CNFLead(II) complexes were much lower than that of CNFs. Peak at 3260 was disappeared and the red shift of other peaks proved interaction between lead and chitin nanofiber (Figure 6d).

sections.heading: 3.6. Effect of contact time and Kinetics Models
sections.text:
The association of heavy metal uptake by Nano-adsorbents with contact time is shown in Figure 7. Contact time is an effective factor in a batch process. The effect of contact time was evaluated by keeping all the parameters, including temperature (298.15 K), initial concentration of lead ions (100 ppm), adsorbent dose (1 g/l), pH (5), agitation speed (250 rpm) constant, and changing contact time of the process. As presented in the figure 7, adsorbed lead for both adsorbents rises as the contact time lapses. In the first 20 minutes, lead uptake increased rapidly, with increasing duration of exposure to the adsorbents. With further elapse of time, lead uptake rises with less gradient, and the amount of lead ions uptake approached equilibrium within 60 minutes (green sphere and rectangle) for both CNFs and CNPs. The rapid initial increase in lead uptake is probably due to vacant active sites at the beginning of the adsorption process. As the contact time passes, the rate of lead uptake lowers because of active sites occupation.(Sivakami, Gomathi, Venkatesan, Jeong, Kim & Sudha, 2013) According to figure 7, it is obvious that after 60 minutes there is no significant change in the lead uptake amount and it becomes constant since vacant active sites are almost occupied by metal ions after 60 minutes.
The pseudo-first and second-order kinetics models expressed as the following equations:
Ln (Qe - Qt) = ln Qe – K1t (5)
t / Qt = 1/ (k2 Qe2) + t / Qe (6)
where k1, k2 , Qe and Qt are the pseudo-first order adsorption rate constant (min-1), the
second- order rate constant (g mg-1 min-1), and the values of lead amount adsorbed per unit of adsorbent mass at equilibrium and at any time t, respectively. The first-order kinetics model shows that the adsorption controlled by a diffusion step.(Liu et al., 2013) The graphs of kinetics models for adsorption of lead with CNFs and CNPs are shown in figure 8 and demonstrate that the seconed-order plots have better linearity.
The results in Table 2 show that first-order model have high deviation with respect to the
experimental value.

sections.heading: 3.7. Evaluation of Adsorption Isotherm Models
sections.text:
Different isotherm models such as Langmuir and Freundlich, (Jamali, Tehrani, Shemirani & Morsali, 2016) are fitted to equilibrium data obtained from the experiments for describing the distribution of adsorbed species between the liquid phase and solid phase.
Langmuir model (Jamali, Tehrani, Shemirani & Morsali, 2016) is founded on this
assumption that the adsorbent surface has sites with equal affinity to the molecules. This equal affinity, causes each site to be occupied by only one molecule. Therefore, the absorption process occurs in a single layer. Furthermore, Langmuir isotherm assumes that adsorption sites have equal energies, and presence of a molecule on one site, does not impress on the adsorption of other molecules in the other sites. The Langmuir isotherm equation can be expressed as the following equation:

Figure 9 shows Langmuir adsorption isotherms for chitosan nanoparticles and chitin nanofibers the results illustrate that for chitosan the plot is linear and the adsorption is monolayer.

As can be seen in figure 10 for chitin nanofibers Freundlich isotherm is linear, although it is not linear for chitosan nanoparticles.
For considering the compatibility of equilibrium data with Langmuir and Freundlich
isotherms, diagrams of (7) and (9) equations for CNFs and CNPs were plotted and the required information were extracted and listed in Table 3.
According to the information obtained, correlation coefficient (𝑅2) for CNFs in Freundlich isotherm is closer to 1 respect to Langmuir isotherm and for CNPs this coefficient in Langmuir isotherm is closer to 1. Hence, for CNFs Freundlich isotherm model compared to Langmuir isotherm model can fit better with the equilibrium adsorption data, and adsorption process is predicted to occur on the heterogeneous surface much better than single layer process. Similarly, for CNPs Langmuir isotherm model has more compatibility with adsorption data, and adsorption process is predicted to befall as a single layer process. Moreover, 𝑅𝐿 amount for CNPs, and 1 𝑛 amount for CNFs are between 0 and 1, that this represents the compatibility of Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms with equilibrium data for CNPs and CNFs respectively.

sections.heading: 3.8. Thermodynamic studies
sections.text:
The thermodynamic parameters can be determined from the thermodynamic equilibrium constant, K0 (or the thermodynamic distribution coefficient). The standard Gibbs free energy change ΔGo (KJ mol−1), standard enthalpy change ΔH0 (KJ mol−1), and standard entropy change ΔSo (J mol−1 K−1) were calculated using the following equations:(Boparai, Joseph & O’Carroll, 2011)

equilibrium (mg/l).
ln K0 was plotted versus 1/T to calculate ΔHo and ΔSo from the slope and intercept,
respectively (Figure 11).
For temperatures of 298.15 K, 313.15 K and 328.15 K procedures were performed and
results illustrated that the best lead uptake obtained at the temperature of 298.15 K. In the following thermodynamic parameters are presented in Table 4:
As can be seen in Table 4 the adsorption process for chitosan is more rapid, and
thermodynamic parameters for both Nano-adsorbent in 298.15 K is the best.
Gibbs free energy change of adsorption (ΔG°) was calculated using ln K0 values for
different temperatures. It was found as −1.469, −0.606 and −0.098 KJ/mol for the adsorption of Pb(II) onto chitin nanofibers at 298.15, 313.15 and 328.15 K, respectively, and as −3.022, −1.385 and −0.339 KJ/mol for the adsorption of Pb(II) onto chitosan nanoparticles at 298.15, 313.15 and 328.15 K, respectively. The negative ΔG° values indicated that the adsorption of Pb(II) onto chitin nanofibers and chitosan nanoparticles were practical and spontaneous thermodynamically. In addition, the decrease in ΔG° values with increase in temperature shows that the adsorption was not favorable at higher temperatures. The enthalpy change (ΔH°) and entropy change (ΔS°) for the adsorption process were obtained from the ln K0 versus 1/T plot (Figure 11). The ΔH° parameter had a value of −15.137 KJ/mol for CNFs and -29.781 KJ/mol for CNPs. The negative ΔH° value indicated exothermic nature of the adsorption. The ΔS° parameter were found to be −46.05 J/mol K for CNFs and −90.01 J/mol K for CNPs, implying that the Pb(II) in bulk phase (aqueous solution) were in a much more disordered distribution compared to the relatively ordered state of solid phase (surface of adsorbent).

sections.heading: 3.9. Comparison of adsorbed lead amount of CNFs and CNPs with other
sections.text:
adsorbents As presented in Table 5, adsorbed lead amount of some adsorbents for removal of lead (II)
ions have been compared with chitin nanofibers and chitosan nanoparticles. Other compared adsorbents are not biocompatible and cause more environmental impacts, furthermore maximum adsorbed lead amount of these synthesized adsorbents are lower than adsorbed lead amount of adsorbents used throughout this investigation. In addition, CNFs and CNPs were synthesized facile and fast. Between chitin nanofibers and chitosan nanoparticles, CNPs show better performance for lead ions elimination under same conditions, due to free nitrogen donor agents that act the same as Lewis base.
Nanofibers and nanoparticles of chitin and chitosan were used to remove lead metal ions
from aqueous solution. These absorbents, compared to usual adsorbents with usual structure size, due to their higher surface to volume ratio, have much greater ability to interact with water molecules, heavy metals and other contaminants in the water. This feature added to other specific features of chitin and chitosan polymers in binding with heavy metals, lead to efficient adsorption of heavy metals from aqueous solutions.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, CNFs were prepared successfully with a novel mechanical and CNPs were prepared with chemical procedure. The size and morphology of prepared Nano-adsorbents were characterized using scanning electron microscopy. These low-cost and environmentally friendly
Nano-adsorbents were applied, for separating lead metal ions from aqueous solution. A batch technique was employed for the adsorption process. During the experiments, the effect of various parameters, such as initial concentration, pH value, Nano-adsorbents content and contact time were investigated. The results indicate that both Nano-adsorbents, due to high surface area and different functional groups can eliminate lead ions from aqueous solution efficiently. It was observed that, lead uptake for CNPs was greater than CNFs at all the stages. CNF has a fibrous structure containing crystals while CNP was precipitated from solution and its crystallinity is very low or it is totally amorphous. The supermolecular structure difference between CNF and CNP causes lead ions to have a different amount of accessibility to active sites of two adsorbents. Active sites, in CNP due to amorphous structure are more accessible and metal ions are more trapped in amorphous structures and consequently, the amount of lead uptake for CNP is greater than CNF. This further efficiency, is due to free amine groups in chitosan repeating rings that have a great affinity to bind with metal ions. The optimum elimination pH value for both adsorbents was observed equal to 5. Although both adsorbents, especially chitosan, demonstrate a rapid removal of lead ions, the process reaches to equilibrium within 60 minutes and kinetics models showed that the adsorption following by second-order kinetic model. In addition, the adaptability of equilibrium results with adsorption isotherms was researched, and it was found that Freundlich and Langmuir isotherms fitted better with experimental data for CNFs and CNPs respectively. Furthermore, kinetics and thermodynamic studies showed repectively that CNPs perform the adsorption process more rapid and spontaneous in respect to CNFs.

referenceMentions.context: The adsorption process involves a solid adsorbent, which binds the molecules through chemical bonding, ion exchange and physical attractive forces (Demirbas, 2008).
Chitin Nanofibers are generally described as fibers with the diameter size less than 100 nanometers (Qi & Xu, 2004; Xia et al., 2003).

The same adsorption mechanism is happening for chitin, except that chitin has –NCOCH3 instead of –NH agents which causes weaker complexation between chitin and lead ions (Cadogan, Lee, Popuri & Lin, 2015; Guibal, 2004).
